Should address #94 as a part of refactor.

My original comment was more just because I was having trouble understanding what was going on. I was thinking that if you did `"> 5%` vs `"> 0.25%"` you would end up transpiling _less_ because more modern code would be supported. But I guess it simply is not possible to transpile `async/await` to some lesser used browsers?

In any case, I don't think we need to spend much time on this, unless you are really curious to. We should support `async/await` because students should be free to use it, but there is really no reason to worry about old browsers.
Sounds good, I won't necessarily prioritize this task, but I might explore it bc I'm definitely curious!

Closing this PR. Future work will be done on my fork until version 2 is complete and we are back in maintenance mode again.

Hey @ScottRudiger! **How are you running your tests?**

When I followed https://github.com/hyperledger/education-cryptomoji/blob/master/code/part-one/README.md#getting-started-and-running-tests by running `npm test`, I didn't hit any `Invalid Chai property: hexString` errors on my end.

However, when I ran `mocha 01-Signing.js` (from `/code/part-one/tests/`), I ran into the `Invalid Chai property: hexString` error as the contents of https://github.com/hyperledger/education-cryptomoji/blob/master/code/part-one/tests/index.js hadn't run yet.

Thanks Robin; yeah, I was running mocha on the individual test file because I didn't want to see 30+ failing tests. :) It works perfectly fine if you run all the tests and include the custom chai property in `index.js`.

@delventhalz @taylorpage We have some rudimentary viewing & selecting of sires happening now! This PR is ready for review.

-----

### Viewing a Moji's Details

When viewing a nonsire that belongs to you, you have the option of selecting that moji as a sire (and upon a successful response from the server, will add a üé© emoji immediately to the moji's parsed DNA).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7613067/41887809-f5097818-78c7-11e8-8ab1-99d78aa727e5.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7613067/41887827-0e8ace5e-78c8-11e8-9bbb-588dc2ab52a9.png)

-----

### Viewing a Collection

When viewing a collection, sires are noted by a different background color and a üé© emoji.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7613067/41887839-1921b80a-78c8-11e8-8b7f-28fb490516df.png)

-----

### Tradeoffs of Current Implementation

Currently, each `<MojiItem />` being rendered in a `<Collection />` makes its own AJAX call to determine if it's a sire or not. This is so that the `<MojiItem />` can be reused in other situations where moji are not strictly rendered in a collection (eg, listing all available sires, listing all moji to be traded in an offer, etc).

https://github.com/hyperledger/education-cryptomoji/blob/dd3d2b38ec59471735b0e28bea37e707f53a32d4/code/part-one/tests/01-Signing.js#L69
Should take Buffer as it shown in [the documentation](https://github.com/cryptocoinjs/secp256k1-node/blob/master/API.md#signbuffer-message-buffer-privatekey--object-options---signature-buffer-recovery-number)

The use of `randomBytes` to create random messages for testing has caused some confusion. The simplest `sign` implementation will likely handle either strings or Buffers fine (because `createHash` handles both strings and Buffers), so I was not particularly specific about which to accept. This is clarified in a new PR (referenced below):

- part one's sign method must be able to handle strings
- part two's sign method must be able to handle Buffers

I think we can either:
1. cherrypick your newest work into `hyperledger:signup-login` and then make a PR from `hyperledger:signup-login` to `hyperledger:master`
2. drop the duplicate commits from `taylorpage:signup-login` and force push back to `taylorpage:signup-login`
3. use GitHub's "squash while merging" functionality

FYI, #69 introduces a number of API changes to client services, and will break much of the code here. I'm assuming this will get merged first, and then I will update these API calls as a part of #69.

Sorry, no bitcoin users here. This is an educational course for Hyperledger Sawtooth, an enterprise blockchain completely distinct from bitcoin. A private key is a secret known only to the user who controls the funds, so if you were trying to withdraw from someone else's account you would get an error. Or perhaps your private key is just mis-entered or something. Beyond that, I have no ideas. I would recommend looking for a support forum for the bitcoin wallet you are using.
Max how much you offer me to get your privatekey?

Hi, tell me how much you want? I can pay you about 100 btc for this work.
But i need to be sure that nobody steal that btc from that address. I know
its someone else bitcoin address but thats my friend.

Out of date

@delventhalz ah, I think I might've figured out why

1. did a fresh `git clone` operation in a separate directory
2. ran `docker-compose up` from `/code/part-two/`
3. ran `npm install` and `npm run build:dev` from `/code/part-two/client/`
4. loaded up http://localhost:8000/, and interacted w/ the webpage from there, which seems to work for me

HOWEVER, reloading the web page when at anything but http://localhost:8000/ (OR attempting to go directly to http://localhost:8000/browse/moji_cat1) seems to result in a 404 bc Apache isn't configured to serve `index.html` for unknown routes (?). Soooo I guess back to React Router's `<HashRouter />` (instead of `<BrowserRouter />`) unless we can config Apache to work for this SPA?

@therobinkim Ah, okay. Hrmm. I've always used Apache in the past with hash routes. I haven't configured Apache to serve a SPA properly without the `#`, but it should be possible. No idea how much of a pain it would be though . . .

Alright I found this blog post:
https://ngmilk.rocks/2015/03/09/angularjs-html5-mode-or-pretty-urls-on-apache-using-htaccess/

And I added this to line 16 of client/Dockerfile:
```
LoadModule rewrite_module modules/mod_rewrite.so\n\
RewriteEngine On\n\
RewriteCond %{DOCUMENT_ROOT}%{REQUEST_URI} -f [OR]\n\
RewriteCond %{DOCUMENT_ROOT}%{REQUEST_URI} -d\n\
RewriteRule ^ - [L]\n\
RewriteRule ^ /index.html\n\
\n\
```

This got rid of the 404's, but I'm still not seeing anything display on the page other than the search bar still. I will try to debug further tonight.

Ah, I forgot to `npm run build:dev`!

Okay, the Apache fix works. If you could add a commit that adds the above code to the Dockerfile, I am satisfied.

@delventhalz Added new lines for client's Dockerfile, but the new changes didn't work for me. :( When I'm at http://127.0.0.1:8000/browse/collection_cats1 or http://localhost:8000/browse/collection_cats1 and refresh, I get a 404. I've committed my work and updated my PR so you can see what I tried, in case I updated the wrong file or something. Any suggestions on how to proceed? In the meantime, I'll continue prepping my next PR.

FYI I _did_ make sure I ran `docker-compose up` _after_ making changes to the Dockerfile, but I don't know if my setup caches any older versions of the Dockerfiles or not.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7613067/38699035-8dbef05c-3e5c-11e8-985a-fd647e09e47c.png)

> client         | 172.18.0.1 - - [12/Apr/2018:19:19:49 +0000] "GET /bundle.js HTTP/1.1" 200 949752

> client         | 172.18.0.1 - - [12/Apr/2018:19:20:39 +0000] "GET /bundle.js HTTP/1.1" 200 949752
@therobinkim You have to `docker-compose up --build` if you want to rebuild the docker images. I tested it and it works fine if you rebuild. Approved.

This looks really good! I have been updating the design doc for this application and I know we were talking about whether or not to convert this to more modern javascript so I will be happy to make those changes to these files once we have more concrete answers. Nice work!

This should wait to be merged until we have the directory structure worked out.

Also, I believe in the final repo we will want stub prompt files to be in `master` while the answer files are in their own branch (`solution`?), under the same file name. I'm not sure what our workflow should be for getting to that point, but I think it probably makes sense to merge one file into `master` _with_ the solution code (and the prompt comment above the solution if you've written it). Then later once we have everything working, we can make a new branch and delete the solution code from `master`.

Note that this PR doesn't follow the Contributing workflow of:

1. **Fork repo**
2. Make feature branch
3. Submit PR

We don't necessarily need to close this PR, but for future PRs let's observe that pattern. I don't want us pushing to upstream and accidentally erasing something.

@lsavage92 @TheeSweeney There are some changes I would like to see, but this seems generally reasonable to me. How do you two feel about the overall structure? Is this what you guys had in mind for an intro sprint? Other than tests, is there anything missing?

@taylorpage Could you move the contents of `intro/` to `code/part-one/`, and also "merge" the `prompt` and `solution` files into one file, with the stub comment above the solution code? Let's just call it `blockchain.js`.

Later, when it comes time to take all of the solution code out of master and create the solution branch, this will make it a lot easier.
